questions.text:
A 40-year-old patient presents with a dilated pupil that reacts poorly to light but constricts on accommodation. A lesion of the ciliary ganglion is suspected. Which of the following statements regarding the ciliary ganglion are true?
1. Located between the optic nerve and tendon of medial rectus
2. Contains sensory fibers via the nasociliary nerve
3. Motor (parasympathetic) root arises from fibers of oculomotor nerve to inferior oblique
4. Parasympathetic root originates from Edinger-Westphal nucleus
5. Sympathetic root supplies sphincter pupillae muscle
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ciliary Ganglion:

  • A parasympathetic ganglion in the orbit.
  • Serves as a relay station for fibers that control the sphincter pupillae (pupillary constriction) and ciliary muscle (accommodation).
  • Topographically linked to the nasociliary nerve (ophthalmic division of trigeminal).
  • Functionally linked to the oculomotor nerve.

Location:

  • Found near the apex of the orbit.
  • Lies between the optic nerve (medially) and the origin of the lateral rectus muscle (laterally). (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • The ophthalmic artery runs on its medial side.

Branches:

  • The ganglion gives rise to 15-20 short ciliary nerves.
  • These pierce the sclera around the optic nerve and run forward in the suprachoroidal space.
  • They carry all three types of fibers:
    • Parasympathetic → to sphincter pupillae & ciliary muscle
    • Sympathetic → to dilator pupillae & ocular vessels
    • Sensory → from eyeball structures

Roots:

1. Parasympathetic (motor) root:

  • Originates from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus in the midbrain.
  • Fibers travel in the oculomotor nerve, reach the nerve to inferior oblique, and then enter the ganglion.
  • Synapse occurs within the ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibers exit via short ciliary nerves to supply:
    1. Sphincter pupillae → pupillary constriction
    2. Ciliary muscle → accommodation reflex

2. Sympathetic root:

  • Preganglionic neurons arise from T1 spinal segment.
  • Relay occurs in the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion.
  • Postganglionic fibers form the carotid plexus, pass through the ganglion without synapse, and reach the eye through short ciliary nerves.
  • Supply: Dilator pupillae and orbital blood vessels. (Statement 5 ruled out)

3. Sensory root:

  • Derived from the nasociliary nerve (ophthalmic division of trigeminal).
  • Fibers pass through the ganglion without relay.
  • Provide sensation (pain, touch, temperature) from the eyeball (cornea, iris, ciliary body).

Clinical Note:

  • Damage to the ciliary ganglion produces a dilated, unreactive pupil.
  • Light reflex is lost, but accommodation is relatively preserved (light-near dissociation, e.g., Adie's pupil).

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lingual nerve passes in very close proximity to the submandibular gland and its duct, making it particularly vulnerable to injury during gland resection.

Functions affected if the lingual nerve is damaged:

  • Loss of general (touch, pain, and temperature) sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • Loss of taste sensation in that same region, since the lingual nerve carries taste fibers from the chorda tympani (branch of the facial nerve).
  • Possible reduction in saliva secretion, because the chorda tympani carries parasympathetic fibers that stimulate the submandibular and sublingual glands.

Course:

  • The lingual nerve arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve (V3) in the infratemporal fossa.
  • It courses downward and forward, lying initially medial to the lateral pterygoid muscle and deep to the ramus of the mandible.
  • As it enters the floor of the mouth, it runs superficial to the hyoglossus muscle and deep to (and looping under) the submandibular duct, before ascending to supply the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  • This intricate relationship places it at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

Explanation of Other Options:

Nerve to mylohyoid (Option A): A branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (V3) that innervates the mylohyoid and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle. Injury affects floor-of-mouth muscle function, but does not impact tongue sensation, taste, or salivation.

Inferior alveolar nerve (Option B): Traverses the mandibular canal to supply sensory branches to the lower teeth, the chin, and lower lip. Not anatomically related to the submandibular gland, so its injury would not explain deficits in tongue sensation or taste.

Hypoglossal nerve (Option D): Provides motor innervation to all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except palatoglossus). Damage causes deviation of the tongue toward the affected side and motor impairment, but would not produce sensory or taste loss.

Reference:

Anatomy, Head and Neck, Lingual Nerve - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf.

questions.text: A lesion in the Brodmann area 22 will cause:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brodmann area 22 corresponds to Wernicke's area, located in the superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (usually left). A lesion in this area causes Wernicke's aphasia, also known as receptive aphasia, characterised by impaired comprehension and fluent but meaningless speech (word salad).


Explanation for other options:

Expressive aphasia (Option A): Expressive aphasia (Broca's aphasia) results from a lesion in Brodmann area 44 & 45 (Broca's area), causing non-fluent speech with intact comprehension.

Poor repetition of language (Option C): This is characteristic of conduction aphasia, which occurs due to damage in the arcuate fasciculus, disrupting communication between Wernicke's and Broca's areas.

Poor naming (Option D): While naming impairment can occur, it is not specific to Wernicke's aphasia; anomic aphasia primarily affects naming ability.

questions.text: A student experiences jaw locking during a yawn. Spasm of which muscle, attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint, is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral pterygoid muscle is the only muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ).

  • It plays a key role in the movement of the TMJ, particularly in opening the mouth and moving the jaw forward (protraction).

Lateral pterygoid:

  1. Attachment: The superior head of the lateral pterygoid inserts into the articular disc and the joint capsule, while the inferior head attaches to the neck of the mandible.
  2. Function: It helps in:
    • Depressing the mandible (opening the mouth).
    • Protrusion and lateral movements of the jaw.
  3. Spasmodic contraction: During excessive yawning, prolonged contraction of the lateral pterygoid can pull the articular disc and the mandible forward, potentially leading to jaw locking due to dislocation of the TMJ.

Explanation for other options:

Temporalis (Option B): This muscle primarily elevates and retracts the mandible; it has no attachment to the articular disc.

Medial pterygoid (Option C): Assists in elevation and side-to-side movements of the mandible but is not connected to the articular disc.

Masseter (Option D): A strong elevator of the mandible; also has no attachment to the articular disc.

Reference: Anatomy, Head and Neck, Mastication Muscles - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

questions.text: A patient presented with vision loss. On radiological investigation, an aneurysm causing damage to the optic chiasma was noted. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be the artery that is causing the damage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The optic chiasma is positioned just above the anterior communicating artery (AComA) in the suprasellar cistern.

  • AComA aneurysms are the most common intracranial aneurysms.
  • These aneurysms can compress the optic chiasma, resulting in bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes).
  • Clinical presentation may include vision loss, headache, and if ruptured, subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Anterior choroidal artery (Option B):

  • Branch of the internal carotid artery.
  • Supplies the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and posterior limb of internal capsule.
  • Aneurysms are rare and usually cause contralateral motor deficits, not compression of the optic chiasma.

Middle cerebral artery (Option C):

  • Does not run close to the optic chiasma.
  • MCA aneurysms typically affect the lateral convexity of the brain, leading to contralateral hemiparesis, aphasia (dominant hemisphere), or hemineglect (non-dominant hemisphere).

Anterior cerebral artery (Option D):

  • Courses superior to the optic chiasma.
  • ACA aneurysms generally do not compress the chiasma directly.
  • ACA infarcts are classically associated with contralateral leg weakness due to involvement of the paracentral lobule.

Reference: Anterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm Related to Visual Symptoms - PMC

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with sudden-onset diplopia. On examination, his right eye is medially deviated at rest, but pupillary reaction is normal. Imaging shows an aneurysm of the cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery. Which cranial nerve is most likely affected first?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure C is the Abducent nerve (CN VI), which lies medial to the cavernous internal carotid artery and is the first cranial nerve affected in cavernous ICA lesions.

Cavernous Sinus Anatomy:

The cavernous sinuses are paired venous plexuses lying on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone. They extend from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone, with an average length of 2 cm and width of 1 cm. The sinus cavity is formed by separation of the two layers of dura covering the anterior pituitary:

  • Outer (endosteal) layer: forms the anterior (sphenoidal) wall.
  • Inner (meningeal) layer: remains attached to the pituitary and forms the medial (sellar) wall.

Relations of Cranial Nerves within the Cavernous Sinus:

  • Lateral wall: CN III (oculomotor - label A), CN IV (trochlear - label B), and CN V1 (ophthalmic - label D) travel in the lateral dural wall.
  • Medial/inferolateral aspect: CN VI (abducent) runs within the sinus proper, adjacent to the cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery (ICA), passing through Dorello's canal.

Clinical Correlation:

  • CN VI lies medial and closely related to the cavernous ICA, making it most vulnerable to compression from aneurysms or high-flow fistulas.
  • Clinical feature of CN VI palsy: inability to abduct the eye → medial deviation (esotropia), diplopia.
  • CN III, CN IV, and V1 are initially spared because they are embedded in the lateral wall, protected from early compression.
  • Progressive lesions can later involve CN III (ptosis, pupillary changes) and V1 (loss of corneal reflex).

questions.text: An 8-year-old child underwent bilateral tonsillectomy. After a few days, he developed a temporary loss of sensation over the posterior one-third of the tongue. On examination, the gag reflex was absent. Which cranial nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) lies in close relation to the tonsillar fossa.
  • During or after tonsillectomy, postoperative edema or surgical trauma can transiently compress this nerve.
  • Functions of CN IX relevant here:
    • Provides general sensation and taste to the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    • Supplies sensation to the oropharynx and palatine tonsil.
    • Forms the afferent (sensory) limb of the gag reflex.
    • Note: Vagus nerve forms the efferent (motor) limb of gag reflex).

Hence, injury or compression explains:

  1. Loss of posterior 1/3 tongue sensation, and
  2. Absent gag reflex (afferent defect).

Explanation of Other Options:

CN VII (Facial nerve) (Option A):

  • Provides taste to anterior 2/3 of tongue (via chorda tympani).
  • No role in sensation of posterior 1/3 or gag reflex.
  • Therefore, not involved here.

CN VIII (Vestibulocochlear nerve) (Option B):

  • Purely sensory, mediates hearing (cochlear) and balance (vestibular).
  • Unrelated to tongue or pharyngeal sensation.

CN X (Vagus nerve) (Option D):

  • Provides motor innervation to pharyngeal muscles.
  • Forms the efferent (motor) limb of the gag reflex.
  • Lesions cause palatal droop, nasal regurgitation, hoarseness, but not sensory loss in posterior tongue.

Key Takeaway:

choices.text: Anosmia due to damage to olfactory filaments
Intracranial spread of infection via emissary veins
Conductive hearing loss due to middle ear involvement
Visual loss due to optic nerve compression

questions.text: An injury leading to disruption of the structures passing through the foramen cecum is most likely to cause which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The foramen cecum is a small midline opening at the junction of the frontal bone and ethmoid bone.
  • It normally transmits a small emissary vein connecting the nasal mucosa veins with the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Clinical significance: This venous communication can act as a potential route for spread of infection from the nasal cavity to the intracranial venous sinuses, predisposing to dural venous sinus thrombosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anosmia due to damage to olfactory filaments (Option A): Anosmia occurs due to damage to olfactory filaments traversing the cribriform plate of the ethmoid, not the foramen cecum.

Conductive hearing loss due to middle ear involvement (Option C): Conductive hearing loss results from middle ear pathology (e.g., otitis media, ossicular chain defects) or Eustachian tube dysfunction, unrelated to the foramen cecum.

Visual loss due to optic nerve compression (Option D): Visual impairment arises from lesions involving the optic canal (which transmits the optic nerve and ophthalmic artery), not from foramen cecum involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is NOT innervated by the pharyngeal plexus of the vagus nerve (CN X)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pharyngeal plexus (formed mainly by fibers of the vagus nerve, with contributions from cranial part of accessory nerve and sympathetic fibers) supplies:
    • All muscles of the palate (Options A and C ruled out) (except tensor veli palatini)
    • All muscles of the pharynx (Option D ruled out) (except stylopharyngeus)
    • Palatoglossus, the only tongue muscle not supplied by hypoglossal nerve
  • Stylopharyngeus is the sole muscle of the pharynx supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

questions.text: Identify the structure passing through the foramen highlighted.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The highlighted foramen is the mandibular foramen, which lies on the medial surface of the ramus of the mandible, approximately opposite the occlusal plane of the molar teeth.
  • It serves as the entry point for the inferior alveolar neurovascular bundle (inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve [V3], and the inferior alveolar vessels).
  • After passing through the foramen, this bundle travels in the mandibular canal, supplying the mandibular teeth.
  • The foramen is guarded anteromedially by a bony projection called the lingula, which gives attachment to the sphenomandibular ligament and is an important landmark for inferior alveolar nerve block anesthesia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lingual nerve and artery (Option A): The lingual nerve lies medial to the mandible, does not enter the mandibular foramen.

Mental nerve and vessels (Option C): These are terminal branches of the inferior alveolar nerve and vessels, emerging at the mental foramen, not the mandibular foramen.

Mylohyoid nerve and vessels (Option D): The mylohyoid nerve branches off before the mandibular foramen, running in the mylohyoid groove to supply the mylohyoid muscle and anterior belly

choices.text: Its floor is formed by the mylohyoid muscles
It contains submental lymph nodes draining the tip of the tongue and lower lip
Small veins within it unite to form the anterior jugular vein
It is paired, one on each side of the midline

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient presents with a midline swelling just inferior to the chin. On examination, the swelling is soft, fluctuant, and drains intermittently. A surgeon suspects involvement of lymphatic structures within a small anatomical triangle bounded laterally by the anterior bellies of digastric muscles, with its apex at the chin and base at the hyoid bone. Which of the following statements regarding this anatomical region is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The submental triangle is a single midline triangle (not paired), part of the anterior triangle of the neck.
  • Boundaries: Apex at the chin, base at the hyoid bone, sides by anterior bellies of digastric muscles.
  • Floor: Mylohyoid muscles. (Option A ruled out)
  • Contents: Submental lymph nodes (draining tip of tongue, central lower lip, floor of mouth) and small veins forming the anterior jugular vein. (Options B & C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Surgical Levels of the Neck:

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) has a congenital defect related to the persistent patency of a structure derived from which of the following pharyngeal arches?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ductus arteriosus is a fetal vessel connecting the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta, allowing blood to bypass the lungs.
  • It is derived from the sixth pharyngeal (pulmonary) arch artery.
  • Normally, it closes after birth to form the ligamentum arteriosum. Failure to close results in a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which may cause left-to-right shunting and congestive heart failure if significant.

Explanation of Other Options:

First arch artery (Option A): Most of the first arch artery regresses; its remnants form the maxillary artery and parts of the mandibular/sphenomaxillary arteries.

Third arch artery: Forms common carotid and proximal internal carotid arteries. Unrelated to the ductus arteriosus → not responsible for PDA.

Fourth arch artery: Forms aortic arch (left) and proximal right subclavian (right).

choices.text: Internal laryngeal nerve, Superior laryngeal vessels

questions.text: During a surgical approach to the pharynx, a surgeon carefully dissects the interval between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictor muscles. Which of the following structures passes through this space?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Between superior and middle constrictor muscles:
    • Contains:
      • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) → sensory to posterior third of tongue; afferent limb of gag reflex
      • Stylopharyngeus muscle → elevates pharynx during swallowing
  • Between middle and inferior constrictor muscles:
    • Contains:
      • Internal laryngeal nerve → sensory above the vocal cords (Options C and D ruled out)
      • Superior laryngeal vessels (Options B and D ruled out)
  • Clinical significance:
    • Injury to CN IX → loss of posterior tongue sensation and absent gag reflex
    • Injury to internal laryngeal nerve → loss of laryngeal mucosal sensation above vocal cords, risk of aspiration

choices.text: Septal branch of superior labial artery

questions.text: Which of the following does not arise from the external carotid artery but contributes to Kiesselbach's plexus in the anterior nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior ethmoidal artery is not a branch of the external carotid; it arises from the internal carotid via the ophthalmic artery but contributes to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach's plexus (Little's area):

  • A vascular anastomotic area on the anterior part of the nasal septum, common site of epistaxis.
  • Formed by branches of both external and internal carotid arteries.

Contributing arteries:

  1. From external carotid artery:
    • Sphenopalatine artery (terminal branch of maxillary artery) (Option A ruled out)
    • Greater palatine artery (from descending palatine branch of maxillary) (Option B ruled out)
    • Septal branch of superior labial artery (from facial artery) (Option D ruled out)
  2. From internal carotid artery:
    • Anterior ethmoidal artery (branch of ophthalmic artery, from ICA)

questions.text: Which of the following pierces the buccinator muscle to reach the oral cavity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The parotid duct is the only structure that pierces the buccinator, running deep to the muscle and opening superficially opposite the maxillary second molar.

Buccinator Muscle Anatomy:

  • A thin quadrilateral muscle forming the muscle of the cheek, attached to the alveolar processes opposite maxillary and mandibular molars and to the pterygomandibular raphe.
  • Fibres converge toward the modiolus at the angle of the mouth, interlacing with orbicularis oris.
  • Deep surface: related to buccal glands and oral mucosa.
  • Superficial surface: crossed by facial artery, facial vein, and branches of the facial nerve.

Structures related:

  • The parotid duct (Stensen's duct) pierces the buccinator opposite the upper second molar to open into the oral cavity.
  • The facial nerve runs superficial to buccinator (buccal branches), but does not pierce the muscle. (Option A ruled out)
  • Wharton's duct (submandibular duct) pierces the floor of the mouth, not buccinator. (Option B ruled out)
  • Trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation via buccal branch, but does not pierce the muscle. (Option D ruled out)

Functions of Buccinator:

  • Compresses cheeks against teeth during mastication.
  • Expels air when cheeks are distended (trumpeter action).

choices.text: B - Median aperture of fourth ventricle

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Structure D labelled is lateral apertures of fourth ventricle (Foramen of Luschka), not foramen of Magendie.

The cerebral ventricular system consists of a series of interconnected cavities derived from the central lumen of the embryonic neural tube and the cerebral vesicles:

  1. Lateral ventricles (A):
    • Large cavities within each cerebral hemisphere
    • Communicate at the rostral end with the third ventricle via the interventricular foramen (foramen of Monro, C)
    • Contain choroid plexus, which produces CSF
  2. Third ventricle:
    • Midline, slit-like cavity between the right and left thalami and hypothalamus
    • Caudally continuous with the cerebral aqueduct
  3. Cerebral aqueduct:
    • Narrow tube passing through the midbrain
    • Connects the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle
  4. Fourth ventricle:
    • Wide cavity between the brainstem and cerebellum
    • Normally communicates with the subarachnoid space via:
    • Median aperture (foramen of Magendie, B) - drains CSF into cisterna magna
    • Lateral apertures (foramina of Luschka) - drain CSF into cerebellopontine angle cisterns
    • Caudally continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord
  5. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF):
    • Produced mainly by the choroid plexus in lateral, third, and fourth ventricles
    • Flows in a unidirectional path:
      Lateral ventricles → third ventricle (Monro) → fourth ventricle (cerebral aqueduct) → subarachnoid space (Magendie & Luschka)

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT arise from the nucleus ambiguus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The nucleus ambiguus is located in the lateral medulla oblongata, dorsal to the inferior olivary nucleus. It is a motor nucleus containing special visceral efferent (SVE) fibers. It gives rise to the motor components of CN IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve), CN X (vagus nerve), and the cranial part of CN XI (Accessory nerve). (Options B, C & D ruled out)

CN VII (facial nerve) arises from the facial nucleus in the pons and is therefore not part of the nucleus ambiguus.

Nucleus ambiguus - Function and Muscles Supplied:

  • The nucleus ambiguus controls muscles derived from the 3rd, 4th, and 6th pharyngeal arches, primarily involved in speech and swallowing.
  • CN IX: stylopharyngeus muscle - elevates the pharynx during swallowing.
  • CN X (via cranial XI fibers): most muscles of the soft palate, pharynx, and larynx - responsible for speech and swallowing.
  • Cranial XI fibers (via vagus): contribute to palate, pharynx, and larynx muscles - they "hitchhike" on the vagus nerve to reach target muscles.
  • Exception: Tensor veli palatini is supplied by CN V3.

Course of CN IX, X, and XI:

  • These nerves exit the brainstem lateral to the olive, then leave the skull via the jugular foramen.
  • Cranial XI fibers join branches of CN X to reach pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles.
  • The spinal part of CN XI arises from C1-C5, enters via the foramen magnum, exits through the jugular foramen, and supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius.

Clinical Correlation:

  • Lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome: infarct of lateral medulla → damage to the nucleus ambiguus → ipsilateral weakness of palatal, pharyngeal, and laryngeal muscles.
  • Symptoms include dysphagia, dysphonia, hoarseness, and soft palate droop.
  • CN IX involvement: impaired pharyngeal elevation, loss of gag reflex.
  • Cranial XI fibers (via vagus): impaired speech and swallowing.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with sudden-onset diplopia, ptosis, and a dilated pupil on the right side. MRI angiography shows a saccular aneurysm compressing the oculomotor nerve. Which labelled artery is the most likely site of this aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The oculomotor nerve (CN III) runs between the posterior cerebral artery and the superior cerebellar artery, adjacent to the posterior communicating artery (label C). An aneurysm here is the classic cause of painful third nerve palsy (ptosis, diplopia, pupillary dilation).

Circle of Willis:

The circulus arteriosus cerebri (Circle of Willis) unites the anterior (internal carotid) and posterior (vertebro-basilar) circulations.

  • Anteriorly: two anterior cerebral arteries linked by an anterior communicating artery.
  • Posteriorly: two posterior cerebral arteries (branches of the basilar artery) joined to the internal carotids via the posterior communicating arteries (PComA).

Clinical correlation:

  • Posterior communicating artery (label C) aneurysm is a classic cause of oculomotor nerve (CN III) compression, producing a painful third nerve palsy with ptosis, diplopia, and a dilated pupil due to parasympathetic fiber involvement.
  • Anterior communicating artery (label A) aneurysm is the most common overall, but it typically compresses the optic chiasma, leading to visual field defects. (Option A ruled out)
  • Posterior cerebral artery (label D) aneurysms or basilar bifurcation aneurysms may compress midbrain structures, but are less common causes of CN III palsy. (Option D ruled out)
  • Anterior cerebral artery (A1 segment) (label B) anomalies may impair collateral flow but are not typical sites for aneurysms causing third nerve palsy. (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a content of the interpeduncular fossa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The interpeduncular fossa is a triangular depression located on the ventral surface of the midbrain, forming part of the floor of the third ventricle.

Boundaries:

  • Lateral: Crus cerebri of the cerebral peduncles
  • Anterior: Optic chiasma and optic tracts
  • Posterior: Pons

Contents of the interpeduncular fossa:

  • Infundibulum (pituitary stalk) (Option C ruled out)
  • Tuber cinereum (Option B ruled out)
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Posterior perforated substance (pierced by central branches of posterior cerebral artery) (Option D ruled out)
  • Oculomotor nerve (CN III)

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is not a content of the interpeduncular fossa; it emerges dorsally from the midbrain, wraps around, and passes laterally.

questions.text: A lesion in a patient affects the relay nucleus of the hypothalamus that connects the hippocampus to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, resulting in memory impairment. Functionally, in the Papez circuit of the limbic system, the hypothalamus is placed between which pair of structures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Papez circuit mediates emotional processing and memory consolidation. Its main functional loop:
    Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies (Hypothalamus) → Mammillothalamic tract (MTT) → Anterior nucleus of thalamus → Cingulate gyrus → Parahippocampal gyrus → Hippocampus (Options A, C and D ruled out)
  • The mammillary bodies of the hypothalamus serve as the relay between the hippocampus and anterior thalamus.
  • Damage here interrupts direct functional connectivity between hippocampus and thalamus, leading to anterograde amnesia (seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome).

questions.text: In the schematic diagram of the floor of the fourth ventricle, the marked elevation is produced by which underlying structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The facial colliculus is formed by the underlying abducens nucleus (CN VI), around which the motor fibres of the facial nerve (CN VII) loop dorsally, producing this surface elevation.

Floor of the Fourth Ventricle (Rhomboid Fossa):

The fourth ventricle is a diamond-shaped cavity between the pons and medulla (ventrally) and the cerebellum (dorsally). Its floor = rhomboid fossa, formed by the dorsal surface of the pons and rostral medulla. It is divided into right and left halves by the median sulcus, and each half is further subdivided into medial eminence and vestibular area (separated by sulcus limitans).

Divisions of Floor:

  • Superior triangle (upper part) → apex at cerebral aqueduct, bounded by superior cerebellar peduncles.
  • Inferior triangle (lower part) → apex at obex, bounded laterally by inferior cerebellar peduncles and caudally by gracile & cuneate tubercles.
  • The two parts are separated by striae medullares (transverse fibres from arcuate nuclei → inferior cerebellar peduncle).

Key Surface Features:

Median Zone:

  • Median sulcus → midline groove dividing right and left halves.
  • Median eminence → longitudinal elevation on either side of median sulcus.

Superior Triangle:

  • Facial colliculus → oval swelling on median eminence in lower pons, produced by abducens nucleus (CN VI) with fibres of facial nerve (CN VII) looping around it.
  • Superior fovea → depression along sulcus limitans, lateral to facial colliculus.
  • Locus coeruleus → bluish-grey pigmented area at upper part of sulcus limitans, due to noradrenergic neurons (arousal, stress).

Inferior Triangle:

  • Hypoglossal trigone → overlies hypoglossal nucleus (CN XII), medial.
  • Vagal trigone → overlies dorsal motor nucleus of vagus (CN X), lateral to hypoglossal trigone.
  • Funiculus separans → translucent ridge separating vagal trigone from area postrema.
  • Area postrema → chemoreceptor zone, vomiting centre, lacks BBB (circumventricular organ).
  • Inferior fovea → depression in lower part of sulcus limitans, separating hypoglossal and vagal areas.
  • Obex → caudal tip of fourth ventricle (meeting point of taeniae).

Other Structures

  • Vestibular area → lateral to sulcus limitans, overlies vestibular nuclei (CN VIII).
  • Taenia → narrow white ridges forming inferolateral margins; unite at obex (apex of ventricle).

Explanation of Other Options:

Facial nucleus (Option A): Located in the ventrolateral pons; it contributes to the colliculus only via its fibres, not the nucleus itself.

Vestibulocochlear nucleus (Option C): Located laterally in the pons-medulla junction; not involved in colliculus formation.

Hypoglossal nucleus (Option D): Found in the medulla near the floor of the 4th ventricle; forms the hypoglossal trigone, not the facial colliculus.

choices.text: The spinal cord terminates at the transpyloric plane
The dura mater terminates at the level of S2
The pia mater terminates at the coccyx
The arachnoid mater terminates at the level of S2

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the termination of the spinal cord and its coverings is NOT correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Spinal Cord and Meningeal Termination:

  • Spinal Cord (Conus Medullaris):
    • Adults: Usually terminates at the middle third of L1 vertebral body.
      • Range: T11 (mid-body) to L3 (mid-body).
      • ~25% end below the L1-L2 intervertebral disc.
    • Children (>1 year): Most often at the lower third of L1.
      • Range: T12 (lower third) to L2-L3 disc.
    • Infants (<1 year): May terminate as low as the middle third of L3.
  • Dura Mater (Thecal Sac) :
    • Extends down to S2 vertebra (Option B).
    • Encloses the lumbar cistern → safe site for lumbar puncture.
  • Arachnoid Mater:
    • Closely applied to the inner surface of dura.
    • Also terminates at S2, enclosing the CSF-filled subarachnoid space (Option D).
  • Pia Mater:
    • Adheres to spinal cord surface.
    • Continues beyond conus medullaris as filum terminale internum, then through dural sac as filum terminale externum, anchoring to the coccyx (Option C).

Clinical Correlation:

  • Lumbar puncture:
    • Performed at L3-L4 or L4-L5 interspaces.
    • Cord has ended, but subarachnoid space with CSF persists → avoids cord injury.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not part of the epithalamus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Diencephalon: Development and Subdivisions

The diencephalon (D2) is divided by the hypothalamic sulcus into:

  • Pars dorsalis (dorsal part): forms the thalamus, metathalamus (lateral & medial geniculate bodies), and epithalamus.
  • Pars ventralis (ventral part): forms the hypothalamus and subthalamus.

Developmental Overview

  • The thalamus appears first as a thickening in the dorsal area.
    • With growth, the paired thalami enlarge as ovoid masses, narrowing the cavity of the third ventricle.
    • In some cases, their medial surfaces fuse to form the massa intermedia (interthalamic adhesion).
  • The geniculate bodies (metathalamus) initially appear as surface depressions internally and elevations externally; later displaced laterally by thalamic overgrowth.
  • Epithalamus develops from the roof plate and adjacent dorsocaudal lateral walls. It includes:
    • Pineal gland - arises as a hollow evagination from the roof plate, with a solid distal part and hollow stalk (pineal recess) (Option A).
    • Habenular nuclei - derived from the lateral wall, initially near the geniculate bodies but later separated by thalamic expansion.
    • Habenular commissure - across the cranial wall of the pineal recess (Option B).
    • Posterior commissure - fibers crossing in the caudal wall of the pineal recess.
    • Stria medullaris thalami - is a part of the epithalamus. It is a prominent band of nerve fibres located in the epithalamus and serves as a major connection, carrying signals from various parts of the forebrain, including the limbic system and hypothalamus, to the habenular nuclei." under the heading Epithalamus (Option C).
  • The hypothalamus develops ventral to the sulcus, forming:
    • Mammillary bodies (paired swellings, memory circuit/Papez circuit).
    • Tuber cinereum (gives rise to infundibulum and connects to Rathke's pouch to form the hypophysis).
    • Infundibulum - persists as infundibular recess of the 3rd ventricle.
  • Subthalamus arises as a rostral extension of midbrain tegmentum, containing the red nucleus, substantia nigra, zona incerta, and fiber bundles.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with dizziness and nystagmus. On examination, she has loss of pain and temperature sensation over the right side of her face and the left side of her body. She exhibits ataxia and intention tremor on the right side, affecting both upper and lower limbs, and is unable to perform finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin tests on that side. Additionally, she has hoarseness, drooping of the right eyelid, pupillary constriction on the right, and decreased sweating on the right side of the face. Which of the following arterial occlusions most likely explains her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a classic case of right-sided Wallenberg syndrome (lateral medullary syndrome) caused by occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) or vertebral artery, leading to lateral medullary infarction.


Key Features:

  • Sensory deficits (crossed):
    • Ipsilateral face: Loss of pain and temperature → spinal trigeminal nucleus/tract.
    • Contralateral body: Loss of pain and temperature → lateral spinothalamic tract.
  • Cerebellar signs:
    • Ipsilateral limb ataxia, intention tremor, dysmetria → inferior cerebellar peduncle / spinocerebellar tract
  • Cranial nerve deficits:
    • Hoarseness, dysphagia → nucleus ambiguus (CN IX & X).
  • Autonomic features (Horner syndrome):
    • Ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis → hypothalamospinal tract lesion.
  • Additional features:
    • Vertigo, nausea, nystagmus → vestibular nuclei involvement. 

Explanation of Other Options:

Left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (Option A): Occlusion of the left PICA would cause left-sided lateral medullary syndrome, resulting in ipsilateral facial sensory deficits, C/L body sensory deficits, ataxia, and Horner syndrome on the left side. Since the patient’s signs are right-sided, left PICA occlusion does not match her presentation.

Right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) (Option B): ipsilateral facial paralysis (CN VII), decreased lacrimation/salivation, loss of taste anterior 2/3, hyperacusis, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral ataxia; crossed sensory loss can also occur. Nucleus ambiguus signs (dysphagia/hoarseness) are typical of PICA (lateral medullary), not AICA.

Basilar artery (Option D): Basilar artery occlusion causes bilateral pontine or brainstem infarctions, which can result in locked-in syndrome, quadriplegia, or cranial nerve deficits depending on the level of occlusion. It produces widespread bilateral neurological deficits, rather than the I/L cranial nerve signs with C/L body sensory loss seen in lateral medullary syndrome. Therefore, basilar artery occlusion is inconsistent with this patient’s unilateral pattern of deficits.

Key Takeaway:

Crossed sensory loss + ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits + ipsilateral cerebellar signs + Horner syndrome = classic lateral medullary syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following sulci separates the cuneus from the lingual gyrus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The calcarine sulcus is a deep, longitudinal sulcus on the medial aspect of the occipital lobe. It forms the anatomical landmark separating the cuneus (above) from the lingual gyrus (below).
  • The primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17, V1) is located along the walls of the calcarine sulcus, receiving visual input from the contralateral visual field.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rhinal sulcus (Option B): It is located on the inferior temporal lobe, bordering the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus, unrelated to the occipital lobe.

Parieto-occipital sulcus (Option C): It separates the occipital lobe from the parietal lobe and is positioned posterior to the calcarine sulcus.

Cuneal sulcus (Option D): It is not an officially recognized sulcus in standard anatomical nomenclature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with slow, involuntary, writhing movements of his hands and forearms that interfere with daily activities. There is no resting tremor, rigidity, or cognitive deficit. No history of rheumatic fever or pregnancy is reported. Which of the following basal ganglia structures is most likely involved in producing these movements?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient demonstrates athetosis, which consists of slow, sinuous, writhing movements of the extremities, most commonly the hands and forearms.
  • The globus pallidus, part of the lentiform nucleus in the basal ganglia, is primarily responsible for regulating smooth, coordinated motor activity, and lesions here produce athetosis.

Relationships of Structures Forming Basal Ganglia:



Subthalamic nucleus (Option A): Lesions result in hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging, irregular movements of one side of the body.

Caudate nucleus and putamen (Option B): Degeneration or lesions cause chorea, seen as rapid, involuntary, flicking movements of the hands and face, as in Huntington's disease. Huntington's disease is autosomal dominant with degeneration of cholinergic and GABAergic neurons. Other choreiform dyskinesias include Sydenham chorea (post-rheumatic fever) and chorea gravidarum (second trimester of pregnancy).

Substantia nigra (Option C): Degeneration leads to Parkinsonism (paralysis agitans), which manifests as resting tremor, cogwheel rigidity, bradykinesia, and mask-like facies due to dopamine depletion in the striatum.

choices.text: Thoracic vertebrae have thick, horizontal spinous processes
Lumbar vertebrae have long, downward-inclined spinous processes
Cervical vertebrae have short, bifid spinous processes
Sacral vertebrae have quadrangular, backward-projecting spinous processes

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding spinous processes is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cervical vertebrae: Typically have short, bifid spinous processes, which provide attachment points for muscles and ligaments of the neck.
  • Thoracic vertebrae: Spinous processes are long, quadrangular, and inclined downward, overlapping the vertebra below.
  • Lumbar vertebrae: Spinous processes are broad, thick, and project backward rather than downward, adapted for attachment of strong back muscles.
  • Sacral vertebrae: The spinous processes fuse to form the median sacral crest, not individual quadrangular projections

choices.text: Lateral striate branches of middle cerebral artery
Direct branch from internal carotid artery

questions.text: In the schematic diagram of the internal capsule, which artery primarily supplies the marked area?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The retrolentiform part of the internal capsule, which carries optic radiations and parietopontine/occipitopontine fibers, receives its blood supply predominantly from branches of the anterior choroidal artery.



The internal capsule receives a segmental blood supply from multiple small arteries:

  • Dorsal part of anterior limb, genu, and posterior limb: supplied by the lateral striate (lenticulostriate) branches of the middle cerebral artery (Option A ruled out).
  • Ventral part of anterior limb: supplied by the recurrent artery of Huebner, a branch of the anterior cerebral artery (Option B ruled out).
  • Ventral part of genu: direct branch from the internal carotid artery (Option D ruled out).
  • Ventral part of posterior limb, entire retrolentiform and sublentiform: branches from the anterior choroidal artery.

Reference: Neuroanatomy, Internal Capsule - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf

choices.text: Anterior choroidal artery arises from the cerebral part
Ophthalmic artery arises from the cerebral part
Posterior communicating artery arises from the petrous part
Caroticotympanic artery arises from the petrous part

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding the branches of the internal carotid artery (ICA) are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior communicating artery arises from the cerebral part, not the petrous part.

The internal carotid artery (ICA) is divided into four anatomical segments-cervical, petrous, cavernous, and cerebral-each giving rise to characteristic branches:

  1. Cervical part: No branches.
  2. Petrous part:
    • Caroticotympanic artery: supplies the tympanic cavity. (Option D ruled out)
    • Pterygoid branch: supplies adjacent dura and bone.
  3. Cavernous part:
    • Hypophyseal branches: supply the pituitary.
    • Ganglionic branches: supply the cavernous plexus.
    • Meningeal branches: supply the dura mater.
  4. Cerebral part:
    • Ophthalmic artery: enters the orbit via the optic canal, supplying the eye and orbital structures. (Option B ruled out)
    • Anterior choroidal artery: supplies the choroid plexus of the lateral ventricle, hippocampus, optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule. (Option A ruled out)
    • Posterior communicating artery: connects the internal carotid to the posterior cerebral artery; clinically significant in aneurysms compressing the oculomotor nerve.
    • Anterior cerebral artery: terminal branch supplying medial frontal and parietal lobes and the corpus callosum.
    • Middle cerebral artery: terminal branch supplying lateral cerebral cortex, including areas for motor and sensory control of face, upper limb, and language areas (Broca's and Wernicke's areas).

Clinical correlations:

  • Posterior communicating artery aneurysms → oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Anterior communicating artery aneurysms → optic chiasma compression → bitemporal hemianopia.
  • Middle cerebral artery occlusion → contralateral hemiplegia and sensory loss in face and upper limb; may cause aphasia if dominant hemisphere involved.
  • Anterior cerebral artery occlusion → contralateral leg weakness and sensory loss.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation on the left side of his body and the right side of his face following a brainstem lesion. On examination, vibration sense, two-point discrimination, and stereognosis are intact in all limbs, but he shows ataxia of the lower limb on the ipsilateral side. Which of the following tracts is most likely affected to produce loss of pain and temperature sensation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral spinothalamic tract conveys pain and temperature sensations from the contralateral side of the body. Lesions of this tract result in contralateral loss of pain and temperature below the level of the lesion, while modalities carried by the dorsal columns-such as vibration sense, two-point discrimination, and conscious proprioception-remain intact. This clinical pattern is typical in hemisection or lateral brainstem/cord lesions affecting the spinothalamic pathway.
